sections.title: Robot Study Club
sections.description: The Robot Study Club (RSC) of COEP Technological University is a hub of innovation, where students design, build, and compete with cutting-edge robots. From autonomous systems to AI-driven machines, we push the limits of technology. RSC has earned national and international recognition in competitions like RoboCon, ABU RoboCon, and Techfest, proving our expertise in robotics and automation. Join us as we shape the future of intelligent machines!

sections.title: Robocon Legacy
sections.description: COEP's Robot Study Club has a rich legacy in Robocon, India's premier robotics competition. With years of dominance, we have built some of the most advanced autonomous and manually controlled robots, winning accolades at both national and international levels. Our journey in ABU Robocon showcases innovation, teamwork, and engineering excellence, setting benchmarks in precision and performance.

Notices: National Robocon 2019: 2nd Runner-Up in MathWorks Modeling Award
National Robocon 2018: Best Aesthetic Robot Award
ABU Robocon 2017 - Tokyo: Nagase Awards, Best Lovely Robot Award
National Robocon 2017: Winners of National Robocon, Fastest Task Completing Robot Award, Best Idea Award, Winner - Matlab Simulation Award
National Robocon 2016: 1st Runner-up, Fastest Task Completing Robot Award, Best Manual Robot Operator Award
Activities: Representing COEP in the prestigious National Robotics Competition - Robocon.
Conducting seminars under The Robotics Society (TRS).
Participating in robotics events at IIT B TechFest, MindSpark.
Building mini-projects and B.Tech projects in robotics and automation.
Presenting research papers at IEEE conferences and Patents.

Timeline.description: Secured 5th in Robocon (Harpoon Throwing). Hosted six Robotica events, including Robowars and Virtual Robotics.
Ranked 13th in Robocon. Conducted industrial robot training. Built a holonomic drive, four-legged robot, and bionic hand.
Ranked 13th in Robocon. Presented 13 papers at ICIT-2021. Built Lagori robots, an underwater ROV, and a swerve drive.
Won 3Kg Sumo at National Robotex. Partnered with Siemens India. Developed a custom PID motor controller.
Founded India's first Student Chapter of The Robotics Society. Developed CAN & RS-485 protocols. Built humanoid torso, ornithopter, and AGV.
Won National Robocon. Developed mecanum drive and electronic pressure regulator for pneumatics.
1st Runner-Up at Robocon. Won MathWorks and Fastest Job Completing Robot awards. Published papers on robotic fish and omni-drive robots.
Won Best Innovative Design (ROHM) and Best Manual Operators at Robocon. Developed badminton-playing robots with 2D LIDAR.
Partnered with Pepperl + Fuchs. Built a quadrotor with IMU stability and a Wall Climbing Robot.

ProjectData.title: Human Assistive Lower Body Exoskeleton
points: Was the runner-up at DRDO Competition
A mechanised exoskeleton that supports extreme weight using pneumatics

ProjectData.title: Vilola: Man-Packable Surveillance Robot
ProjectData.description: Straight out of a spy movie!
points: Uses a camera to stream video
2 Motorised hemispheres allow the robot to traverse
The central cylindrical body is stabilized so that the camera is always facing at the right angle

ProjectData.title: Compressed Air Exoskeleton Suit
points: Uses compressed air technology to enhance physical strength
Ideal for heavy-lifting tasks in industrial and rescue operations

ProjectData.title: 'HALEX' - Human Assistant Limb Exoskeleton
points: A wearable exoskeleton to aid individuals with mobility impairments
Designed for rehabilitation and to enhance physical strength

ProjectData.title: Ornithopter
points: Cycled through two versions of this robot
Latest version is a bird robot that can fly in circles with support
Uses high speed motors to mimic wing flapping
Uses a gyroscope to maintain balance while flying

ProjectData.title: Fish Robot
points: Mimics the movement of a real fish for underwater exploration
Designed for tasks like water quality monitoring and marine life observation

ProjectData.title: Snake Robot
ProjectData.description: Inspired by nature, designed for precision!
points: Mimics the movement of a snake to navigate narrow spaces
Ideal for search-and-rescue missions and pipe inspections

ProjectData.title: Dog Robot
points: A quadruped robot designed to mimic the movement of a dog
Great for search-and-rescue, surveillance, and outdoor exploration

ProjectData.title: Swerve Drive
points: Makes efficient use of every motor action
Uses 2 motors: one for driving and one for direction control
Mechanical coupling is key for driving the gear action

ProjectData.title: Wall Climbing Robot
points: Inspired by the lizard
Uses suction to stick to walls

ProjectData.title: Hydroquadroter
ProjectData.description: Merging air and water for innovative robotics!
points: A quadrotor capable of operating in both aerial and underwater environments
Built for dual-terrain reconnaissance and environmental studies

ProjectData.title: Vertigo
points: Designed to traverse vertical surfaces
Equipped with suction or magnetic wheels for climbing

ProjectData.title: All-Terrain Robot
points: A versatile robot capable of navigating rough and unpredictable surfaces
Suitable for exploration, military, and disaster response scenarios

ProjectData.title: Humanoid Robotic Arm
points: A versatile arm designed to mimic human movements
Ideal for tasks requiring precision such as assembly and object manipulation

ProjectData.title: Multi-Finger Robotic Gripper using Rope and Pulley Mechanism
points: Uses a rope and pulley system for dexterous gripping
Handles delicate and irregularly shaped objects with ease

ProjectData.title: RFID Based Electronic Voting Machine
points: In-house RFID machine for elections during COVID-19
Votes are secured via tags to avoid rigging
Connected to a database that updates with each scan

ProjectData.title: Railway Track Surveillance Robot
points: Monitors railway tracks for faults and obstructions
Equipped with sensors and cameras for real-time data collection

ProjectData.title: 3D Printed Humanoid Robot
points: A fully functional humanoid robot created with 3D printing
Highlights rapid prototyping and cost-effective design

ProjectData.title: Rubik's Cube Solver
points: Built to solve Rubik's Cubes at remarkable speed
Uses computer vision and algorithms for efficient solving

ProjectData.title: Biped Robot
ProjectData.description: Walking like humans, stepping into the future!
points: A two-legged robot designed to mimic human locomotion
Ideal for research in balance and gait analysis

RoboconData.title: 'Harvest Day' 2024, Vietnam
RoboconData.description: The theme is 'Harvest Day', which is inspired by Vietnam's terraced fields. The challenge involves two robots performing tasks related to rice cultivation, such as sowing, harvesting, and transferring grains to silos.
RoboconData.details: First Prize in MATLAB, Won FUSION VISIONARY Award, Placed 8th overall

RoboconData.title: 'Casting Flowers over Angkor Wat' 2023, Phnom Penh, Cambodia
RoboconData.description: The theme was 'Casting Flowers Over Angkor Wat'. The challenge involved two robots, a rabbit and an elephant, working together to toss rings onto poles.
RoboconData.details: Rank 5 and First Runners-Up in MathWorks Modeling Award

RoboconData.title: 'Lagori' 2022 Delhi, INDIA
RoboconData.description: The theme was 'Lagori', a traditional game from southern India. In this game, two teams will design two robots, with each team will take turn playing as seeker and hitter. The seeker's first robot will first break the pile of stones using three small balls. Then the seeker's second robot will rebuild the pile of stones, but it also carries a ball on its head. The hitter's robot would attempt to throw their own balls to dislodge the ball on the seeker's head, and the round immediately ends once they succeeded. The team scores points based on the number of stones they displaced and then rebuilt, with the teams scoring more points declared the winner.

RoboconData.title: 'Throwing arrows into pots' 2021 Jimo, China
RoboconData.description: The theme was 'Throwing arrows into pots' by Jimo, China. The game was based on the traditional game of East Asian countries pitch-pot, or throwing arrows to a pot. In this game, each team designs two robots. One robot can pick up arrows and throw them to the five pots located on the field, but is restricted to the outer area of the field. The other robot, in addition to throwing arrows from the outer area, can navigate through both the outer and inner area of the field, rotating pots, blocking throwing attempts of the opponent, or handing leftover arrows on the field to the first robot. Team scores point based on the number of arrows thrown into each pot, but if a team got the arrow to all five pots, they will achieve the K.O victory which immediately ends the game.

RoboconData.title: 'ROBO RUGBY 7s' Suva, Fiji
RoboconData.description: The challenge was to play rugby 7's with two robots and five obstacles as defending players.

RoboconData.title: 'Sharing the knowledge' Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia
RoboconData.description: The theme 'Sharing the Knowledge' was based on Mongolia's tradition of a message relay system.
RoboconData.details: Ranked 3rd in MathWorks Modeling Competition in National Robocon 2019

RoboconData.title: 'NE'M CO'N' 2018 Ninh Binh, Vietnam
RoboconData.description: The theme for Robocon 2018 declared as ném còn (throwing shuttlecock). The goal of the game is to throw the shuttlecocks through the ring at height.
RoboconData.details: 4th rank at National Robocon 2018 and Bagged Best Aesthetic Robot Award in National Robocon 2018 among 115 teams.

RoboconData.title: 'Asobi: The landing disc' Tokyo, JAPAN
RoboconData.description: The theme revolves around the word 'asobi' (play), which is also a fundamental philosophy behind Robocon. In the match, each team will be given a set of discs which they are supposed to land on the poles of different height and at different distances. Team which will be able to land at least one disc on each pole will be declared as the winner of the game.
RoboconData.details: Winner of National Robocon 2017 among 115 teams. 1st Prize with One lakh prize money. Balkrishna memorial award: Rolling trophy for winning this year national robocon 2017. Bagged Best Idea award, fastest job completing robot. 1st prize for best usage of Mathworks Tools in National Robocon 2017 with 35 Thousands cash prize and subsequently represented India at Internationals.Nagase Award: Special Sponsor award given to Top 6 team among 19 team in International Robocon 2017 held at Tokyo, Japan. Best Lovely Robot: Online polling taken across 18 countries in live contest. Our robot won maximum poll.

RoboconData.title: 'Clean Energy Recharging the World' Bangkok, THAILAND
RoboconData.description: The concept behind the theme is the utilization of renewable energy sources. The match is between 2 teams (viz. red and blue), each team consisting of two robots.
RoboconData.details: COEP secured the first runner-up position in the national competition, Fastest Task Comleting Robot, Best Manual Operator Award, Winner of MATLAB Task Simulation Competition.

RoboconData.title: 'Robominton-Badminton RoboGame' Yogyakarta, Indonesia
RoboconData.description: In the contest, the 2 teams (red and blue) had to play the game of badminton against each other. Each team made 2 robots to play a normal doubles badminton game.
RoboconData.details: Best Manual Operator Award and Best Innovative Design Award by ROHM - Robocon 2015

RoboconData.title: 'A Salute for Parenthood' Pune, INDIA
RoboconData.description: The Theme for Robocon 2014 declared by India was 'A Salute for Parenthood'

RoboconData.title: 'The Green Planet' VIETNAM
RoboconData.description: The Theme for Robocon 2013 declared by VTV was 'The Green Planet'
RoboconData.details: Best Innovative Design Award and One of 2 teams in India to complete task in Robocon 2013

RoboconData.title: 'Pursuit of Peace and Prosperity' HONG KONG
RoboconData.description: The Theme for Robocon 2012 declared by Hong Kong was in Pursuit of Peace and Prosperity.

RoboconData.title: 'Lighting Happiness with Friendship' Bangkok, THAILAND
RoboconData.description: The Theme for Robocon 2011 declared by Thailand was Krathong, Lighting Happiness with Friendship.

RoboconData.title: 'Robo-Pharaohs Build Pyramids' Cairo, EGYPT
RoboconData.description: The Theme for Robocon 2010 declared by Egypt was Robo-Pharaohs Build Pyramids.

RoboconData.title: 'Kago' Tokyo, Japan
RoboconData.description: Theme of Kago, the traditional Japanese palanquin, carried by human beings replaced by robots.

RoboconData.title: 'Govinda' Pune, INDIA
RoboconData.description: The Theme for Robocon 2008 declared by India was Govinda, a traditional Indian Deity who used to play earthly games by capturing Butter/Cheese from heads of Gopis.

CompetitionsData.title: ABU ROBOCON THEME 2024
CompetitionsData.description: Robocon is an International Competition organized by ABU (Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union). This competition is based on various themes in which two robots, one manual and one autonomous, are used to complete a certain set of tasks. The contestants in the competition are undergraduate students who need significant expertise in the fields of Mechanical, Electronics, and Software Engineering to accomplish the given tasks.
CompetitionsData.details: This year's theme focuses on innovative designs that challenge teams to push the limits of robotics and engineering.

CompetitionsData.title: Roboroyale 2024
CompetitionsData.description: Part of Mindspark 2024 and consisted of a manually operated Pick-and-Place Robot

CompetitionsData.title: Entrepreneurship Challenge  Robotex 2024
CompetitionsData.description: The 𝐌𝐚𝐧𝐏𝐚𝐜𝐤𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐑𝐨𝐛𝐨𝐭 features a unique, transformable system that can switch between wheel and track belt configurations, allowing it to adapt to various terrains—whether plain, muddy, or uneven. This flexibility makes it ideal for critical applications such as 𝐬𝐮𝐫𝐯𝐞𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞, 𝐬𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐜𝐡 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐜𝐮𝐞 𝐨𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬, 𝐡𝐚𝐳𝐚𝐫𝐝𝐨𝐮𝐬 𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐚𝐥 𝐝𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧, and 𝐦𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐚𝐫𝐲 𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐧𝐚𝐢𝐬𝐬𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞. Designed to navigate tough conditions, the robot can be deployed in disaster zones, urban search and rescue, and more, offering invaluable assistance where human lives are at risk. Its real-time data transmission capabilities, powered by 𝐑𝐎𝐒2 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐖𝐢-𝐅𝐢 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧, enhance its effectiveness in gathering crucial intelligence in dangerous environments.

CompetitionsData.title: FireFighter 2024
CompetitionsData.description: The FireFighter competition, part of Robotex 2024, consisted of an Autonomous Fire Extinguishing Robot capable of extinguishing candles

CompetitionsData.title: Line Follower Competition at VIIT
CompetitionsData.description: The Line Follower Competition was a part of VIIT Pune's Techfest

CompetitionsData.title: Virtual Robotics 2023
CompetitionsData.description: Part of Mindspark 2022 organized by COEP
CompetitionsData.details: Won First for Stingray Biomimetric Fish Robot and First Runner Up for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle with Horizontal Rotors

CompetitionsData.title: Sumo Robotex 2023
CompetitionsData.description: Part of Robotex India held in 2023

CompetitionsData.title: FIRST Robotics Competition 2023
CompetitionsData.description: The FIRST Robotics Competition is an international high school robotics competition that combines the excitement of sport with the rigors of science and technology. Teams of students build and program robots to compete in a series of challenges.
CompetitionsData.details: In 2023, teams designed robots to compete in a game called 'Charged Up', where they must score points by moving game pieces into designated areas.

CompetitionsData.title: RoboCup 2022
CompetitionsData.description: RoboCup is an international robotics competition that aims to promote robotics and AI research. The competition features various leagues, including soccer, rescue, and industrial robots.
CompetitionsData.details: In 2022, RoboCup hosted its first hybrid competition in Bordeaux, France, where teams participated both in-person and virtually.

CompetitionsData.title: VEX Robotics Competition 2021
CompetitionsData.description: The VEX Robotics Competition provides students with an exciting platform to learn and apply STEM principles. Teams design and build robots to compete in games against other teams.
CompetitionsData.details: The 2021 competition introduced new challenges focused on collaboration and strategy in a virtual format due to pandemic restrictions.

CompetitionsData.title: International Conference on Robotics, Intelligent Automation and Control Technologies
CompetitionsData.description: Students of RSC - 03 PhD, 03 PG students and 02 UG project groups have successfully presented total 08 research papers on Robotics at the International (Virtual) Conference on Robotics, Intelligent Automation and Control Technologies (RIACT 2020) held on 2nd and 3rd Oct 2020 organized by Vellore Institute of Technology, VIT, Vellore, Chennai.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: MindSpark is the annual, national-level technical festival of COEP Tech. Since its inception in 2007, MindSpark has been igniting innovation and creativity. Evolving from modest beginnings, it celebrates intellect, teamwork, and competition. We aspire to give thinkers a stage to speak and creators an opportunity to build by transpiring revolution through innovation.

sections.title: Events Organized by RSC
sections.content: At MindSpark, we host a dedicated module called Robotica, which serves as a hub for all robotics-related events and competitions. This platform showcases a diverse range of challenges, fostering innovation, technical skills, and problem-solving abilities among participants. Through Robotica, we aim to inspire the next generation of engineers and roboticists on a national stage.

sections.title: Impact and Significance
sections.content: Over the years, MindSpark has grown into a pivotal platform for technological innovation, bringing together students, researchers, and industry experts from across the nation. The festival features a wide array of competitive events including Bot Wrestling, Robo Royale, Robo Races, Search and Destroy, Virtual Robotics, and Robo Wars. These events not only test technical skills but also encourage collaborative learning, interdisciplinary problem-solving, and the practical application of engineering principles in real-world scenarios.

sections.title: Transforming Education Through Robotics: An Introduction to Robotex India
sections.content: Founded in 2018, Robotex India is a non-profit organization committed to bridging the digital divide and making robotics, AI, and IoT education accessible to underserved communities across India. With a focus on students from government, rural, and tribal schools, the organization has empowered over 20,000 young minds by offering hands-on learning opportunities. By helping students develop innovative solutions in areas like agriculture, sustainability, and education, Robotex India is paving the way for the next generation of tech leaders in an increasingly technology-driven world.

sections.title: Key Initiatives Driving Impact

initiatives.Inclusive Workshops: The organization conducts workshops in rural and tribal schools, often in areas with minimal resources. These programs introduce students to robotics, AI, and IoT, enabling them to explore technologies they might not otherwise encounter.
initiatives.National Competitions and Global Exposur: The annual Robotex India Championships provide students a platform to showcase their creations in diverse categories. Winners gain the chance to represent India at international events like Robotex International and Robotex Asia, opening doors to global opportunities.
initiatives.STEAM and Robotics Labs: In collaboration with CSR initiatives, Robotex India has established labs in remote schools, promoting hands-on STEAM education and fostering innovation.
initiatives.Sustainability Projects: With a focus on social responsibility, the organization encourages students to develop solutions that align with sustainable development goals, such as waste management, environmental sustainability, and agricultural efficiency.

sections.summary: Through these efforts, Robotex India not only transforms education but also inspires young innovators to contribute meaningfully to their communities and beyond.

sections.title: Our Role in Robotex India Competition
sections.content: At Robot Study Circle, we take immense pride in our pivotal role in organizing the Robotex India National Level Competition, a premier event in the field of robotics and innovation. Held this year at MITADT, we were responsible for overseeing a wide array of responsibilities, including referee work, robot inspection, and volunteering. Our team worked meticulously to ensure that the event ran smoothly and efficiently, maintaining the highest standards of fairness and technical precision.

Our involvement was critical in managing the entire logistics of the competition, ensuring that each participating team adhered to the rules while maintaining the integrity of the competition. As referees, we not only ensured the technical correctness of every robot but also provided guidance and feedback to the participants, helping them improve their designs and performance. The robot inspection process was thorough and systematic, guaranteeing that all the machines complied with the competition’s specifications, ensuring a fair and transparent experience for every team involved.

In addition to our technical roles, we also took charge of volunteering, assisting in managing event operations, coordinating with teams, and ensuring that every aspect of the competition ran without a hitch. Our volunteers played a key role in offering assistance and providing a seamless experience to both participants and organizers. This experience of organizing and managing such a prestigious event has allowed us to strengthen our technical and organizational capabilities, further establishing Robot Study Circle as a key contributor to India’s growing robotics ecosystem. By contributing to the Robotex India National Level Competition, we not only helped execute a world-class event but also created a platform for students, enthusiasts, and professionals to come together, exchange ideas, and foster the growth of robotics and technological education in India. Through these efforts, we continue to uphold our commitment to nurturing the next generation of innovators and ensuring that robotics education remains accessible to all.

sections.title: About FTC India
sections.content: FTC India (FIRST Tech Challenge India) is part of the global FIRST Tech Challenge (FTC) program, aimed at inspiring students to become future leaders in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). It provides students from grades 7 to 12 with a platform to design, build, and program robots that compete in exciting head-to-head challenges.

sections.title: Primary Objectives
sections.content: FTC India organizes robotics competitions where student teams work together to create innovative robots. These robots must complete specific tasks and challenges on a competition field. The competition follows an alliance-based format, where teams form temporary alliances and compete to score points through strategy, precision, and technical skill.

sections.title: Activities
sections.content: At Robot Study Circle, we took great pride in our involvement with the First Tech Challenge (FTC), where we actively contributed as Robot and Field Inspectors and Referees. As a key partner in this prestigious event, we, along with InfinityX—a company with whom we have strong ties—served as volunteering sponsors, ensuring the smooth and efficient execution of the competition.

Our role extended beyond just the technical aspects of the event. We bridged connections with international teams and students, expanding the knowledge base of participants and fostering valuable relationships that enriched the global robotics community. These interactions helped us stay at the forefront of cutting-edge technology while providing our members and students with diverse perspectives from around the world.

In addition to our volunteer roles, we proudly hosted our own stall during the event, where we showcased our latest robotics innovations, shared insights into new technologies, and provided live demonstrations of the robots we had developed. Our participation in FTC was not only an opportunity to contribute to the competition's success but also a platform for us to share our passion for robotics with the larger community and inspire the next generation of engineers and innovators.

sections.title: Community Outreach Program – Mangaon, Raigad
sections.content:
A transformative initiative to bridge technological gaps in rural communities:
 Collaborated with NSS at COEP
 Demonstrated advanced robots: NAO-6 humanoid, RoboSapien, Genibo
 Provided hands-on interaction with cutting-edge robotics
 Inspired local students about potential of AI and robotics
 Connected technical community with rural areas

sections.title: Mathematics Day Robotics Demonstration
sections.content:
Exploring the intersection of mathematics and robotics:
 Showcased NAO humanoid robot, Genibo robot, and Drone
 Demonstrated mathematical principles in robotics
 Highlighted applications in various industries
 Inspired students to explore STEM careers
 Provided interactive learning experience

sections.title: Electronics and Robotics Workshops
sections.content:
Empowering 9th and 10th-grade students with technological knowledge:
 Conducted 2-3 weekly sessions
 Covered electronics and robotics fundamentals
 Provided hands-on learning experiences
 Introduced sensor-based applications
 Motivated students towards STEM disciplines

Dhiraj Patil

introduction: In the last few years, robotics activities in India have moved well beyond the traditional areas of industrial applications, atomic energy, etc., and entered newer domains of education, rehabilitation, entertainment, and even into our homes. Indian robotics researchers have similarly grown from a handful to over a hundred, engaged in research labs, education, industry, atomic energy, and more.

Many of us feel that it is about time to form an academic society to further augment our robotics activities and foster better interaction among ourselves. With this objective, researchers got together to form a society on 10th July 2011. Officially, The Robotics Society was registered on June 21, 2017.
Note that in some of the earlier documents, 'Robotics Society of India (RSI)' might be mentioned, which should be read as 'The Robotics Society,' the registered name of the society.

inauguration.chiefGuest: Mr. Alok Mukherjee (Scientist ‘G’ and Head, Robotics Division, R&DE Dighi, DRDO)
inauguration.director: Dr. B. B. Ahuja, Director of COEP
inauguration.facultyCommittee: Dr. S. S. Ohol, Faculty Committee Member
highlights: The inauguration of the TRS Student Chapter at COEP marked a major milestone in the university's robotics community, with the formal recognition of TRS-SC/18/001.
An upper torso humanoid robot built by COEP’s Robot Study Circle was unveiled during the inauguration, symbolizing the chapter's commitment to cutting-edge robotics.

Mr. Alok Mukherjee, the Chief Guest, delivered a keynote on UAV Netra, discussing its design and applications, and also demonstrated the Unexploded Ordnance Handling Robot (UXOR), showcasing the power of robotics in critical real-world scenarios.
Dr. B. B. Ahuja, Director of COEP, highlighted the importance of Robotics and IoT in the modern industrial landscape, emphasizing their growing relevance for students and industries alike.
Dr. S. S. Ohol introduced The Robotics Society India (TRS) and its mission to foster collaboration and development in the field of robotics, especially at COEP.

The event also laid the foundation for several workshops, including ROS Workshop, Brain-Controlled Robotics, ABB Industrial Robot Training, and many others, aimed at equipping students with advanced skills in robotics.
inauguration.committeeAnnouncement: The inauguration ceremony also saw the announcement of the TRS student chapter committee, marking the beginning of a dedicated team to further TRS activities at COEP.
inauguration.felicitation: As a part of the event's conclusion, the Robot Study Circle members who represented India at the International Robocon 2017 in Tokyo, Japan, were felicitated and awarded Certificates of Appreciation for their exceptional achievements.
inauguration.emphasis: This event marked the beginning of a new era for COEP’s robotics community, with the TRS Student Chapter playing a pivotal role in bridging the gap between students, academia, and the robotics industry. The inauguration not only celebrated the formal establishment of the chapter but also set the stage for future collaboration, innovation, and skill development in the rapidly evolving field of robotics.

activities.title: Activities
activities.description: The Robotics Society organizes a main event every year around the month of July. The events are Advances in Robotics (AIR) and Workshop on Robotics, held alternatively.

airEvents.title: Advances in Robotics (AIR)
airEvents.description: Advances in Robotics (AIR) is an international conference of The Robotics Society, held every two years. Below are the details of past AIR events:
events: AIR2013 at R&DE, DRDO, Pune during July 4-6, 2013
AIR2015 at BITS Pilani Goa Campus, Goa during July 2-4, 2015
AIR2017 at IIT Delhi, New Delhi, during June 28 – July 1, 2017
AIR2019 at IIT Madras, Chennai, during July 2-6, 2019
AIR2021 at IIT Kanpur, Kanpur during June 30 - July 4, 2021 (fully online)

workshops.title: Workshops on Robotics
workshops.description:
The Robotics Society (TRS) Student Chapter at COEP Technological University provides students with a unique opportunity to learn from industry experts and robotics enthusiasts. Our workshops feature engaging sessions where speakers showcase their robots, share insights on emerging technologies, and discuss advancements in the field. These interactive experiences offer students valuable exposure to real-world robotics, inspiring them to innovate and explore new possibilities. The workshops include:
 Demonstration of NMR 145 Customized Mobile Manipulator Robot by Mr. Aditya Marathe: A demonstration showcasing the NMR 145, a customized mobile manipulator robot, with insights into its design, functionality, and real-world applications.
 Demonstration of RoboDK Software: A session on RoboDK, a versatile software used for simulation, programming, and controlling industrial robots, with practical examples of its usage in optimizing robotic workflows.
 Interaction Session with Esteemed RSC Alumni, featuring Dr. Pratap Tokekar (Associate Professor, Maryland University) and Dr. Abhishek Nagaraja (Associate Professor, Berkeley University): A discussion on their journey in robotics research, insights into academia, and advice for students pursuing careers in robotics.
 Workshop and Demonstration of Industrial Robot by Rigbetel Labs: A hands-on session introducing students to industrial robots, with demonstrations on their programming and applications in manufacturing, automation, and logistics.

introduction: The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) is a global professional association dedicated to advancing technology for humanity. With over 400,000 members across 160+ countries, IEEE serves as a hub for engineers, researchers, and industry leaders in fields like electrical engineering, robotics, electronics, computer science, telecommunications, and beyond. IEEE is best known for setting global technology standards such as Wi-Fi (IEEE 802.11), Bluetooth, and Ethernet, which power modern communication and networking systems. It also publishes some of the world's most respected scientific journals and research papers, organizes international conferences, and offers professional development programs for students and working professionals. By fostering a collaborative ecosystem, IEEE drives technological innovation, supports education, and empowers the global engineering community.

activities.title: Activities
activities.description: Under the banner of IEEE, the Robotics Study Circle (RSC) actively publishes research papers and contributes to advancements in robotics and automation. In collaboration with the TRS Student Chapter, RSC also organizes technical workshops, hands-on sessions, and expert lectures aimed at enhancing student skills in robotics, AI, and emerging technologies. These initiatives provide a platform for students to engage with industry professionals, broaden their knowledge, and contribute to cutting-edge research.

workshops.title: Workshops on Robotics
workshops.description: Workshops on Robotics and its Applications are held every alternate year, focusing on specific thrust areas of robotics.
